newsitem.title: USA: Ill. school funding vote moved to next week.
newsitem.headline: Ill. school funding vote moved to next week.

text.p: Illinois House Speaker Michael Madigan on Friday postponed a planned vote on school financing reform and bond issuance to next week at the request of Gov. Jim Edgar, a spokesman said.
"We think there really is significant support for the bill and it would have passed today (Friday), but the speaker is supportive of the governor," spokesman Steve Brown said.

Edgar sought to delay the vote after negotiations with the Illinois Education Association and Illinois Federation of Teachers went late into the night Thursday, slowing preparation of the package, a spokesman for the Republican governor, Thomas Hardy, said.
"It's a 300-plus page bill, it is complex and House Minority Leader (Lee) Daniels was concerned that there was insufficient time to examine the proposal," Hardy said.
Edgar's plan, backed by the Democratic speaker, would use a 25 percent income tax hike to provide $600 million of new revenues for schools and $900 million of property tax relief.
The proposal would also take $100 million of projected state revenue growth to back issuance of $2 billion of school construction bonds for a matching program with local districts.
The proposal would raise per-pupil spending to a minimum of $4,225 in all Illinois districts, while not reducing aid to more affluent districts which spend much more than that on each student.
Edgar's plan has hit stiff opposition from his own party, however, and the Chicago Tribune reported Friday that he did not have enough House Republicans behind it for passage.
Daniels has questioned increasing the state income tax from three percent to 3.75 percent and recommends combining other taxes to raise base funding for school districts.
Republican Senate President James "Pate" Philip has proposed raising the income tax to 3.4 percent and had pronounced as "dead" the Edgar proposed income tax increase, the Tribune said.
Hardy said Friday that they had expected a close vote on the proposal, but still had expected representatives to approve the legislation.

Lawmakers had hoped to finish their session Friday, but must still reach a budget agreement for fiscal 1998 beginning July 1. Proponents of an electric deregulation plan also seek to introduce a package next week.
